p.seg: Dans l'Antiquité, ceux qui régnaient sur le monde portaient un simple bonnet et un col de fourrure roulé. ["In ancient times there were those who simple caps... and (yet) ruled the world) is the Chinese construction. Not ALL rulers were of this kind. 陳廣忠: 有头戴兜婺翻卷领部而统冶天下的 gets this right, the Westerners seem to get it wrong, and the free Russian version gets nowhere.]

Ainsi, pressé par les difficultés, le peuple cherche ce qui favorise sa subsistance; [§§§§民迫其難"when the people are oppressed by difficulties" is crucial for its generality, and the subject "people" of the Chinese is omitted in the English. The French recognises the new generalising mode of the discourse, using present tense to mark the non-historical mode of this summarising conclusion.

Chacun s'appuie sur ces connaissances [§§§§人各以其知"Man, each using his knowledge" makes no reference to the sages. The failure of the English to respect this seems to seriously distort the argument that is being made here. In 各以其知 the 各 and 其 must be co-referential, for purely grammatical reasons. In any case, the Chinese translators I have seen all take it this way.
